#Text=Prune Rhododendrons
#Text=Rhododendrons are beautiful shrubs/trees that grow in almost all areas of the world .
#Text=They are great for landscaping and produce beautiful flowers in the spring and summer .
#Text=You can keep your rhododendrons healthy and looking the way you want them to by pruning in your style and at the right time of year .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Timing Your Pruning
#Text=Shear your rhododendrons in the winter when you are doing large cuts .
#Text=Winter pruning is better for more shocking trims because the plant is dormant , so its energy is not in its leaves or flowers .
#Text=Cutting in the winter is the best way to ensure that your plant will have new growth after you prune it .
#Text=Try not to prune during a freeze .
#Text=If you cut your plant and the cut branches get frozen , the severe cold may damage or shock the plant .
#Text=Encourage new flowers by pruning right after a bloom .
#Text=If you are just cleaning up your rhododendron or wanting to ensure that your plant gets new flowers next season , you can prune right after your rhododendron is finished blooming .
#Text=This will be in late spring or early summer , or whenever you notice its flowers dying and no new ones starting to grow .
#Text=You can cut flowers off your rhododendron in the middle of spring when they are at their peak to get a beautiful bouquet of flowers .
#Text=This will not hurt your plant .
#Text=Prune before the blooming season to reduce the amount of flowers .
#Text=You can prune in early spring or late winter to discourage your plant from producing as many flowers , and encourage it to put its energy into growing new branches and leaves .
#Text=You should do this if you want your rhododendron to grow larger or taller .
#Text=Rhododendrons are known for their beautiful flowers , so you may want to see your plant with its flowers before you decide to take some away .
#Text=Choosing a Pruning Style
#Text=Cut off dead wood and flowers for a low-maintenance prune .
#Text=The easiest style of pruning is trimming off any dead or dying parts of your rhododendron with pruning shears .
#Text=Dead leaves will look yellow or brown , and dead branches will be crispy and snap easily .
#Text=Cutting off these dying sections helps to put the plant ’s energy back into the parts that are alive and thriving , and will also clean up the overall look .
#Text=Pruning like this only needs to be done once a year , or whenever you notice your rhododendron needs it .
#Text=Pruning only the dead parts of your plant will also help promote a more natural , less landscaped look for your rhododendron .
#Text=Prune a shape into your plant when you are trying to control its growth .
#Text=You can encourage your rhododendron to grow in a certain direction or area by cutting back the parts you want to be smaller , and leaving the parts you want to be larger .
#Text=This is helpful when your rhododendron is near your house , or when you are trying to keep a more uniformed look .
#Text=This type of pruning only needs to be done once a year .
#Text=Rhododendrons will only conform to a shape to a certain extent .
#Text=They have broad leaves and longer branches , so they may not ever look completely uniform .
#Text=Trim it down to above the ground for a new look .
#Text=This pruning method is a reset for your plant .
#Text=You should choose this method if your rhododendron is messy looking or overgrown and you want it to try growing again .
#Text=Most species of rhododendrons will be able to survive this method of pruning , but a few cannot , so it is worth researching your specific type before using this method .
#Text=Some healthy rhododendrons can even be cut down to above the ground , but it ’s recommended that you try first to see if your plant will survive .
#Text=You should not use this method if your rhododendron is sick or especially old , because it is more likely to be shocked and not revive after such a harsh cut .
#Text=Trimming Your Plant
#Text=Decide what tool you need for your rhododendron size .
#Text=Older and more established rhododendrons may need a chainsaw to cut through the large woody branches , especially toward the middle of the plant .
#Text=Hand saws and pruning shears are helpful for smaller , less established branches , or when you are cutting less of the rhododendron .
#Text=Tools can break or become dangerous when used improperly .
#Text=You should always read the manual and operating instructions of any tool before you use it .
#Text=Ask for professional help if you need it .
#Text=Large , tree-like rhododendrons can sometimes require an expert to take care of them .
#Text=You can check with your local landscaping company to see if they offer the services you need .
#Text=Cut branches in straight , even strokes .
#Text=Try to avoid bending or breaking the branches of your rhododendron .
#Text=Instead , use your tool to cut the branches evenly and in straight lines .
#Text=This will cause less damage to your plant , and will lessen the chances of it going into shock or dying .
#Text=You can make your cuts on any part of the branch , unless you are trying to avoid flowers , in which case you only need to look out for buds or flowering parts of your plant .
#Text=Place a tarp beneath the area you are cutting for an easier cleanup of branches and leaves .
#Text=It might be easier to break off the dead branches , which will not hurt your plant , since they are already dead .
#Text=Clean up any excess branches and leaves that fall on the ground .
#Text=You ’ll want to tidy up the space you have been working in once you are done pruning .
#Text=This will keep your rhododendron looking neat and your yard looking organized .
#Text=This step is optional , but it is essential if you want your yard to look well-kept .
#Text=If your city has a yard debris program , you can put your cut branches in your yard debris bin .
